selected_quotes: Different in vitro proliferation and cytokine-production inhibition of memory T-cell subsets after… #immunetolerance
#Cy #Immunology Different in vitro proliferation and cytokine-production inhibition of memory T cell subsets after…

citation.abstract:
Calcineurin (CNI) and mTOR inhibitors (mTORi) are the main immunosuppressants used for long-term maintenance therapy in transplant recipients in order to avoid acute rejection episodes. Both groups of immunosuppressants have wide effects and are focused against the T cells, although the different impact on specific T cell subsets, such as regulatory T cells (TREG ), has been demonstrated. A greater knowledge of the impact of immunosuppression on the cellular components involved in allograft rejection could facilitate the decision of individualized immunosuppression when an acute rejection event is suspected. Memory T cells have recently gained focus since they might induce a more potent response as compared to naïve ones. The impact of immunosuppressants on different memory T cell subsets remains unclear.
In the present study, we have studied the specific impact of CNI (Tacrolimus) and mTORi (Rapamycin and Everolimus) over memory and naïve CD4(+) T cells. To do so, we have analyzed the proliferation, phenotypic changes and cytokine synthesis in vitro in presence of these immunosuppressants.
The present work shows a more potent effect of CNI on proliferation and cytokine production in naïve and memory T cells. However, the mTORi permit the differentiation of naïve T cells to the memory phenotype and allow the production of IL-2.
Altogether, our data show evidence for the combined use of CNI and mTORi in transplant immunosuppression. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.
citation.title: Different in vitro proliferation and cytokine-production inhibition of memory T cell subsets after calcineurin and mTOR inhibitors treatment
